OREG4PEETZRMP
Executive Summary

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Description of Corporate Prevention and Emergency Response Approach

This OREG 4, Inc. (OREG4) Recovered Energy Generation (REG) facility complies with 
numerous standards for pressure vessel design and testing as well as all Federal and Colorado 
process safety management requirements. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, 
and local laws. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses and process safety 
management plans and all technical drawing (P&IDS) for process equipment are maintained onsite 
for reference. Regular inspection and testing of the pentane and thermal oil systems are performed 
to ensure equipment integrity is maintained. The facility is equipped with a network of leak 
detection equipment, automatic shutdown logic controls, insulation, safety relief valves, fire 
detection monitors. OREG4 provides high levels of training in operating procedures, safety and 
emergency response. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to implement the emergency 
response procedures to mitigate damages, and to notify the nearest fire department and request 
their assistance.

Description of Stationary Source

The OREG4 power units are fueled by waste heat from a compressor turbine exhaust that is 
transferred from thermal energy into mechanical energy. This is accomplished by utilizing the 
organic Rankine cycle (ORC) technology. The hot gases of the turbine exhaust flow through a 
Waste Heat Oil Heater (WHOH), where the heat from the gases is transferred to a thermal oil heat 
transfer fluid. The thermal oil is then circulated to the shell and tube vaporizer of an Ormat Energy 
Converter (OEC). The motive fluid on the shell side is vaporized and these vapors drive a special 
organic fluid turbine. This turbine, which rotates at 1800 rpm, drives a generator which produces 
grid compatible power. The motive f1uid then passes through a heat exchanger and en

ters the 
cycle again as a liquid. After exiting the various heat exchangers, the thermal oil passes through 
the thermal oil surge tanks and the thermal oil feed pumps, which discharge it into the WHOH. 
The power from this project will be sold to Highline Electric Association based in Holyoke, CO.

The basic Rankine cycle model consists of four components:
1. Pump -Work Input
2. Boiler -Heat Input
3. Turbine -Work Output
4. Condenser -Heat Rejection

The Rankine cycle consists of pressurizing a liquid (pentane), vaporizing the high pressure liquid, 
expanding the high pressure vapor and condensing the low pressure vapor for reuse. The energy 
necessary for the vaporization is provided by thermal oil at a maximum temperature of 572?F. The 
thermal energy is transferred to the pentane working fluid via tube and counter-current shell heat 
exchangers. The OREG4 facility uses a commercial pentane with a dry cooling heat rejection 
system.

Primary Activities 

Waste thermal energy is converted to electric power. The facility is rated at 3700 KW. The net 
power output to the electrical grid is rated at 3200 KW. Power output is reduced in warm weather 
due to limitations of the air cooled heat exchangers.

Use of Regulated Substance

Pentane, a flammable vapor/liquid is used as a binary working fluid. Liquid pentane is pumped 
from a condenser to shell and tube heat exchangers. Thermal energy provided by thermal oil is 
transferred to the pentane. The thermal oil heat input causes the pentane to change physical states 
from liquid to high pressure superheated vapor that is passed through a turbine to produce electric 
power. The vapor is condensed and recycled back to a pressurized liquid recuperator vessel to 
complete the Rankine cycle. A pentane storage tank is available for makeup. The facility design is 
segregated into multiple sections, each having its own design specifications dictated by the 
pentane conditions in that section. The sections include: the low pre

ssure process equipment, the 
high pressure process equipment, pentane unloading system, vapor recovery system, evacuation 
system and non-condensable removal system. Each section is protected by pressure relief systems 
that may include pressure safety valves, pressure control valves, control system shutdown and 
intervention logic and administrative practices.

Quantities Handled or Stored

The design inventory of the system consists of pentane present both as a gas and as a liquid. The 
nominal maximum liquid inventory exists when the facilities are not operating. At that time the 
energy in the pentane is reduced and most of the inventory is present as a liquid in the liquid 
recuperator vessels. The following chart indicates the normal maximum inventory at this facility.

Worst Case Scenario Description

Worst case scenario is based on a vapor cloud explosion. Although safeguards are in place, that 
makes a worst case scenario extremely unlikely, it was assumed the explosion originates at the 
OEC recuperator with all equipment in vapor and liquid service. The total pentane material is 
20,000 kg.

Examination of topographic maps and visual observation of the potentially affected area in a 
worst case scenario did not identify any residential structures, parks or other public places. 
OREG4 Peetz REG facility is located in a relatively isolated area surrounded by farmland. The 
facility is approximately 13.8 miles east-northeast of Peetz, CO.

Prevention Program Description

Safety Information:

Maintenance procedures: OREG4 has installed and operates a Computerized Maintenance 
Management software (CMMS) program. This CMMS contains information on all equipment in 
the facility requiring maintenance, inspections, testing, certification, calibration, etc. NFPA, 
OSHA, manufacturer's recommendations and operations experience have been utilized to produce 
a comprehensive maintenance work order system that produces maintenance requests at 
appropriate frequencies. Employees report any equipment deficiencies to the operation and 
Maintenance Manager who generates "work orders" for the repair or assessment of the problem. 
Routine comprehensive inspections are performed using checklists.

Emergency Response Plan: The emergency response plan is intended to identify and coordinate 
personnel in the event there is an emergency.

Training: some equipment in the OREG4 facilities poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical 
hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if saf

ety procedures 
are not fol1owed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, 
identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites. These subjects include electrical safety, 
fire prevention and protection, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, gas 
detectors, fire panels, personal protective equipment, and the safe use of tools and equipment. 
Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Industrial Hygiene and Standard safety 
procedures Manuals.

Callout procedure: If any of the following alarm conditions are indicated by the OREG4 
monitoring system, this call-out procedure must be followed: OEC failure, OEC low output, 
security/fire alarm trip. If any of these events should occur the monitoring staff will immediately 
contact the Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manager. If the O&M Manager is not reached in a 
timely manner the parent company, Ormat Nevada Inc. will be notified on the 24 hour phone 
number (775) 852-1912. If a fire is detected the monitoring staff shall notify local emergency 
personnel including fire and police departments.

Notification of Trailblazer Pipeline Personnel: Any Trailblazer Pipeline personnel which may be at 
the site during the alarm condition must also be notified through Trailblazer Pipeline procedures. 
Trailblazer Pipeline personnel should not attempt to respond to the alarm conditions unless they 
have been trained and certified to do so. The principal methods of accident prevention include 
equipment design safeguards, written procedures and operator/employee training. Safety systems 
are present in the facilities and have various methods of operation.

Pressure safety systems typically have three levels of degree. The initial degree is an alarm that is 
presented audibly and visually to the Control Room Operator. The next more severe degree is a 
shutdown of process equipment likely to be causing or exacerbating the condition and an alarm 
that is presented audibl

y and visually to the Control Room Operator. The third and most severe 
degree of pressure safety system are pressure safety valves (PSV) which relieve to atmosphere or 
to larger low pressure systems. Some of these PSV's also have Control Room Alarms.

A combustible gas detection system is present in each of the plants. Sensors are strategically 
located in each plant. Control Room audio and visual alarms annunciate concentrations in excess 
of 40% of LEL.

Process Hazard Analysis

OREG4 utilized a professional safety consultant experienced in organic Rankine power cycles to 
perform a hazard analysis appropriate to the complexity of the process for identifying, evaluating, 
and controlling hazards involved in the process and shall determine and document the priority 
order for conducting process hazard analyses based on the extent of process hazards, number of 
potentially affected employees, age of the process, and process operating history. A Hazop 
analysis was selected and utilized.

An analysis was performed on the power cycle. The Hazop analysis was performed on the 
Alliance Kerrobert REG project which is similar to the OREG4 plants with only a few minor 
differences:

1. Increased number of Air cooler bays in OREG4
2. A minor Increase in generator rating (in OREG4)

Accident History

OREG4 Peetz REG facility does not have an accident record, since it is a new facility.

Emergency Response Plan

OREG4's Emergency Response is based on recognition and observation of potential emergency 
conditions, and immediate repair, or notification of the primary response agency. The policy for 
emergency response at OREG4 is to mitigate any accident by implementing emergency procedures 
that have been developed for all known contingencies. Small fires will be contained and mitigated 
with fire extinguishing equipment and automatic suppression systems. Emergency notification is 
required for any release or threatened release of a hazardous material which poses a significa

nt 
present or potential health, safety or environmental hazard. The O&M Manager is designated 
incident command when present. The senior operator is designated incident command when 
management is not present. Incident command is transferred to emergency responders upon 
arrival.
